title: 106_hr1652
content: The Act titled "Yukon River Salmon Act of 1999" establishes the Yukon River Salmon Panel. The Yukon River Salmon Panel advises on international agreements with Canada, restoration of salmon stocks, and other conservation functions. The Secretary of State may designate Panel members as US representatives on bilateral bodies. The Yukon River Salmon Panel advises on international agreements with Canada and restoration of salmon stocks. The Panel is comprised of six members, including one US government official and one Alaska state official with expertise in salmon conservation. The Yukon River Salmon Panel advises on international agreements with Canada and restoration of salmon stocks. It is comprised of six members, including one US government official and one Alaska state official with expertise in salmon conservation and management. The panel also includes four members knowledgeable about salmon fisheries on the Yukon River, appointed by the Secretary of State based on nominations from the Governor of Alaska. The Governor of Alaska nominates members for the Yukon River Salmon Panel, with at least one member representing Lower Yukon River fishing districts and one representing Upper Yukon River fishing districts. One member appointed must be an Alaska Native. Alternates can be designated by the Secretary of State and the Governor of Alaska for Panel members. The Governor of Alaska may designate an alternative Panel member to serve in the absence of the appointed member. Panel members and alternates serve four-year terms and are eligible for reappointment. Decisions are made by consensus of the Panel members. Panel members may consult with other interested parties in carrying out their functions. The Governor of Alaska may establish an advisory committee of 8-12 individuals knowledgeable about Yukon River salmon fisheries, including at least 2 Alaska Natives. Committee members serve two-year terms, without compensation, and are eligible for reappointment. The Panel and advisory committees established under section 3 are exempt from the Federal Advisory Committee Act. The Panel has authority and responsibility. The State of Alaska Department of Fish and Game is designated as the responsible management entity for salmon stocks from the Yukon River in Canada. This designation does not change the management authority of Alaska or the Federal Government. The Panel may make recommendations on salmon conservation to the Department of the Interior. The Panel may make advisory recommendations on salmon conservation originating in the Yukon River to various Federal and State entities. SEC. 6. ADMINISTRATIVE MATTERS. Panel members and alternate Panel members who are not State or Federal employees shall receive compensation at the daily rate of GS-15 of the General Schedule when engaged in the actual performance of duties. Travel and other necessary expenses will be paid by the Secretary of the Interior for all Panel members, alternate Panel members, and members of any advisory committee. They are not considered Federal employees while on duty, except for injury compensation or tort claims liability as provided in chapter 81 of title 5, United States Code. YUKON RIVER SALMON STOCK RESTORATION AND ENHANCEMENT PROJECTS. The Secretary of the Interior, in consultation with the Secretary of Commerce, may carry out projects to restore or enhance salmon stocks from the Yukon River in Canada and the United States. If there is an agreement between the US and Canada for the conservation of Yukon River salmon stocks, projects will be carried out according to the agreement and funds may be deposited in a joint account for such projects. Authorization of appropriations is provided. Authorized appropriations of $4,000,000 annually for fiscal years 2000-2003 to the Secretary of the Interior for travel expenses of Panel members, Joint Technical Committee members, and advisory committee members under the Pacific Salmon Treaty. Authorized appropriations of $4,000,000 annually for fiscal years 2000-2003 to the Secretary of the Interior for travel expenses of Panel members, Joint Technical Committee members, and advisory committee members under the Pacific Salmon Treaty. Such sums are available for the United States share of expenses incurred by the Joint Technical Committee and any panel established by agreements between the US and Canada for salmon restoration. Additionally, funds are allocated for activities related to salmon stocks from the Yukon River in Canada and cooperative salmon research and management projects. Cooperative salmon research and management projects in the Yukon River drainage in the United States recommended by the Panel.
